reviews.text: Upon arrival, reception dealt with us swiftly and lead us to our rooms. They ended up offering us an upgrade to the Kastberg suite instead of two separate rooms for three of our five night stay, which we gladly accepted. The Kastberg is situated in the building with the restaurant in it, up a spiral staircase to a lounge area with a very wide double bed and a vast selection of built in wardrobes. The lounge area has a writing table, coffee table and ample seating. This room leads via three sets of patio doors to a small ante-lounge with a small table and more seating. Turn left to a huge bathroom with a shower, toilet, bidet and double tub (bath) (with Jacuzzi jets which we didn’t try because the wiring in Morocco scared us a bit, but we are boring British folk). It takes a good few minutes for the hot water to arrive out of the tap, so long in fact, we were convinced there was no hot water; only to be proved wrong by a very patient member of staff. Anyway, the ante-lounge has another door leading to a twin room. Both bedrooms have aircon/heating/climate control, which was very handy given the five days of non-stop rain (very rare apparently) and we can confirm the heating works fine. If it does rain, please do not expect the rooms to be watertight. Various puddles appeared and the walls in the bathroom turned a darker shade due to wetness. This is Southern Morocco and it rarely rains, so no-one really knows how to plan for it – a bit like London when it snows. The last two nights were spent in rooms 18 & 19. These were sold as a single and a double – although both had two beds each. Also the double room key opened the single room door – useful for parents needing access to a teenage room. These rooms had a sofa, table, triple wardrobe and a five piece ensuite.
reviews.title: Shabby chic, relaxed oasis

reviews.text: The grounds are wonderful. There are plenty of places for a teenager to go and sulk, away from nosey parents. The pool was big but unheated, which normally would not be a problem (if no rain....bbrrr.). Plenty of sunbeds, with umbrellas and a vast selection of trees and folly buildings to hide from the sun/rain. The whole site is either a bit shabby or in the process of being built, slowly. If you are prepared for shabby chic, then this place is for you. Orange and grapefruit trees everywhere, although the small green fruits are not limes, as we thought, just a weird orange.
reviews.title: Absolutely stunning and very friendly!

reviews.text: The staff were very friendly. Only one member of staff spoke English, which proved more entertaining than inconvenient. We thought once we had ordered bread, but meat arrived – hey, who cares, we are on holiday; we should have learnt holiday Arabic or French.
reviews.title: A good place to stopover

reviews.text: Food was a bit hit and miss. The couscous was divine, the tagine show stopping, the kebabs tasty – but they tried to be European and put easy cook rice and frozen chips on the side, which ruined things a bit for me. If someone could just convince them to stick to Moroccan stuff, we would have been much happier. Coffee at breakfast was a fair filter not instant. The orange juice freshly squeezed. The pancakes delicious. The omelette was a bit rubbery, but again, if they stuck to Moroccan food, the outcome would be far nicer. Mint tea was served in the afternoon and we ordered it regularly during the day, which was nice and warming whilst the rain came down.
reviews.title: Beautiful for holiday makers, not great for business
Hidden treasure
reviews.text: Bring your own alcohol as they have none. They are happy to provide wine glasses, etc. We brought our gin and vodka duty free to have a post dinner drink with their superb freshly squeezed orange juice .
